author: Special Correspondent
text:
A group of academics and parents under the aegis of the Foundation For Rights of Young Child (Foryouchild) has urged the State government to move the Supreme Court for a stay on its interim order exempting CBSE schools in Tamil Nadu from the purview of the Fee Fixation Committee.

The order passed on January 28 effectively gives liberty to around 600 CBSE and ICSE schools to fix their fees.

The schools had challenged the Tamil Nadu School (Regulation of Collection of Fees Act 2009).

The signatories to a statement issued by the foundation said that with more matriculation schools moving to the CBSE/ICSE system, the government should appeal against the Supreme Court order.

It pointed out that by a circular (no. 2 dated 21/2/2011), the CBSE, Delhi, had directed the schools to abide by the regulation of the State Act.

Hence the State government should amend the code of regulations for approved nursery and primary, matriculation and Anglo-Indian schools and include the CBSE schools in its ambit, it said.

‘Make NOC conditional’

Since the CBSE schools maintain that they are out of government control once the ‘No objection certificate’ is issued and the schools receive CBSE affiliation, the State government should make NOC conditional by adding the clause that all State government Acts and rules would be applicable to CBSE schools also.

The Supreme Court order had given liberty to 600 schools to fix

their fees
title: Govt. urged to move SC against order on fee in CBSE schools
